title-group.article-title: Financial Reporting Quality, Debt Maturity, and the Cost of Debt: Evidence from China

abstract.p: This paper investigates the influence of different financing channels—bond issuance or bank loans—as well as debt maturity and the quality of financial reporting on the cost of debt in China. The authors find that conservative accounting is an important characteristic of high-quality financial reporting that can reduce the cost of longer maturity debt such as bank loans and bonds. Even state-owned enterprises, which have fewer financial constraints than non–state-owned enterprises, benefit from accounting conservatism's ability to reduce financial costs. Moreover, the findings indicate that bond investors are concerned about the issuer's fundamentals, while banks are more likely to focus on the operation and bankruptcy risk of borrowers.

ref.mixed-citation: According to Cheng (2007), 85 percent of listed firms' debt acquired from 2000 to 2005 was short-term debt (less than one-year maturity).

Since both ownership structure and capital structure affect reporting policy, conservative reporting may be the intermediate variable, not the determinant variable. Actually this relationship can show the role conservative reporting plays in debt financing, namely, that investors and banks judge risk based on conservative accounting. In general, conservative accounting is an important characteristic of high-quality accounting information and plays an important role in reducing information asymmetry. Of course, in order to reduce the influence of the ownership structure on financing costs, we control for those factors in empirical regressions.

Conservative accounting will lead to lower current accounting earnings, significantly af- fecting profitability, which is the key risk measure in bank lending. In particular, conservative accounting has a negative influence on borrowing due to its negative effect on earnings. Thus, for short-term debt financing, although conservative accounting may help obtain debt financing, it may also have the opposite effect. Thus, the relationship between conservative accounting and financing costs is not clear.

Comparable loan interest rates are the interest rates on bank loans that have the same matu- rity and are issued at the same time as bonds in public bond markets. We also use the comparable deposit interest rate; the results are basically the same. To save space, they are not reported in the main text.

Ball et al. (2008) find that the influence of conservatism on debt pricing is mostly due to conditional conservatism, not unconditional conservatism. The measure of conservatism in our paper, the cumulative accrual, actually consists of both aspects. Therefore, we compare conditional and overall conservatism and find that both have improved since 2001 in China, as do Xia and Zhu (2009). Overall conservatism can be a proxy for conservatism. Givoly et al. (2007) suggest that a single measurement for conservatism has too much measurement error, so we use other kinds of conservatism, such as market value to book value (M/B) (Feltham and Ohlson 1995; Khan and Watts 2009; Moerman 2008) and the C-score developed by Khan and Watts (2009) based on Basu's (1997) model.
Using the previous year's conservative accounting measure can minimize the influence of concurrent agency problems on conservative accounting.

New accounting standards issued in China in 2007 are different from the previous standards and make comparison of financial data impossible. We use only the issuances before 2008 and do not cover financial data for 2007.
The conservatism measure is the three-year cumulative accrual. Since we need at least three years of data, we omit firms that have been listed for less than three years.
Results for the nominal financing interest rate are basically the same as for the interest spread.
Results using Conservl, and the results for Conserv2 are basically the same. To save space, we do not report these results.
If the annual financial report for the previous year has not been released, we use the annual financial report for the year before the previous year.

Conserv is the same as Conservl'. three-year cumulative accruals are multiplied by -1, thus the higher this measure, the higher the accounting conservatism (Ahmed and Duellman 2007; Xia and Zhu 2009). The accruals for each year are equal to earnings minus cash flow from operations, divided by total assets at year end. We also use Conserv2 and the results are basically the same. To save space, we do not report the results. Due to limited information, we do not have the Z-score. Thus this regression does not include this variable.
Since most of the new sample firms are not listed, we do not use M/B or the C-score as robustness tests.
